##matrices
* matrices are vectors with a *dimension* attribute;
* like vector, matrices must must contain objects of the same class;
* matrices are constructed column-wise.

```{r}
#create a matrices
mat <- matrix(1:6, ncol = 3, nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)  # byrow=FALSE is default
mat
attributes(mat) # view the main attribute of the variable
dim(mat)

rep(5,3)
rep(c(1,5),3)
rep(c(1,5),each=3)
```
```{r}
#another way to creat a matrices
x <- 1:10 # x right now is still a vector
dim(x) <- c(2,5)
x #after set the attribute of dim, the vector become matric
```
```{r}
x <- rep(5,3) # repeat 5 three time and creat a vector
y <- 11:13
mat <- cbind(x,y) #combind the x and y in col
mat
mat <- rbind(x,y)
#combind the x and y in row
mat
class(mat) #after combine two vectors the matric formed
```
```{r}
## creat and change the names of matrices
mat
dimnames(mat) <- list(c('a','b'),c('c','d','e'))
mat
colnames(mat) <-c('Alpha','Beta','Gamma')
mat
rownames(mat) <- c('red','green')
mat
```

## list
* list is a special type of *vector* that can contain elements of **different** type;
```{r}
x <- list(1,'a',TRUE,1+4i)
x
```
* we can give the name to the vector and list
```{r}
vec1 <- c('welcome','to','columbia') #this is a vector of characters

names(vec1)
names(vec1) <- c('w1','w2','w3')
names(vec2) <- c('w1','w2','w3','w4')
vec1
vec2 <- c(1,'equals to',1+1i,'is not',TRUE)
vec2
names(vec2)
```
* names can also be given in a different way
```{r}
mylist <- list(stuff=3,mat=matrix(1:4,nrow=2),morestuff=c('china','japan'),list(5,'bear'))
mylist
names(mylist)
```

## dataframe
* unlike the matrices and vectors, data frames can stroe **different** classes of objects in each **column**
* each element of the data frame is a column and the length of each element is the number of rows.
```{r}
x <- data.frame(foo=1:4,bar=c(T,T,F,F))
x
attributes(x)
nrow(x)
ncol(x)
names(x) <- c('cindy','rush')
row.names(x) <- c('00','01','10','11')
x
```
## quick note about naming

|   object   |  set column names  |  set row names  |
|------------|--------------------|-----------------|
|  dataframe |       names()      |    row.names()  |
|   matrix   |      colnames()    |     rownames()  |
